componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from David Manthey of Robert W. Baird.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: First question. In terms of the current quarter, was there any benefit from price at all this quarter? And then given the significant lags, particularly in fasteners, should we expect any incremental pricing as we get to the back half of this year?
componenttext: First question. In terms of the current quarter, was there any benefit from price at all this quarter? And then given the significant lags, particularly in fasteners, should we expect any incremental pricing as we get to the back half of this year?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: You're just seeing very, very limited impact. And I expect to see limited impact as we go to the tail end of the year.
componenttext: You're just seeing very, very limited impact. And I expect to see limited impact as we go to the tail end of the year.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then second, in terms of the vending machines, you say that close to 11% of your sales are to customers that have vending solutions. Could you talk about the revenues per machine? Is it working towards your goal of 25,000? I believe your goal is
componenttext: Okay, and then second, in terms of the vending machines, you say that close to 11% of your sales are to customers that have vending solutions. Could you talk about the revenues per machine? Is it working towards your goal of 25,000? I believe your goal is 25,000 per unit per year.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, our goal is to add 2,000 incremental per machine from each customer. And not all of that will come through the machine and that's fine with us. It's just new business. And yes, the numbers are playing out. If you really make -- if you look at that, y
componenttext: Yes, our goal is to add 2,000 incremental per machine from each customer. And not all of that will come through the machine and that's fine with us. It's just new business. And yes, the numbers are playing out. If you really make -- if you look at that, you have to only look at the customers that have been installed in the last 12 months. And we're above -- ahead of that goal by about 10% to 15% right now. Because the customers are then -- we can get 2,000 incremental year-over-year over year. It's a one-time punch.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Sam Darkatsh of Raymond James.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Sam Darkatsh of Raymond James.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Will, in your prepared remarks, you mentioned expectations in gross margin the rest of the year between 51% and 53%. Is there a way we could hone in a little bit on that based on...
componenttext: Will, in your prepared remarks, you mentioned expectations in gross margin the rest of the year between 51% and 53%. Is there a way we could hone in a little bit on that based on...

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sam, I didn't say the rest of the year. I said our long-term range of gross margin is 51% to 53%. We've been saying that for a long time. Right now I think our gross margin is pretty stable in that range where we've been operating, which is much more -- r
componenttext: Sam, I didn't say the rest of the year. I said our long-term range of gross margin is 51% to 53%. We've been saying that for a long time. Right now I think our gross margin is pretty stable in that range where we've been operating, which is much more -- right in the center of that, about where we are now, a little 52%, 52.5%, 51.9%. But I always like to make sure everyone understands Dan and I are comfortable pretty much anywhere between 51% and 53% that we're operating our business well. Because we think that at some level, the investment community gets too narrowed down on 5 basis points one way or the other. End when you have 2,500 businesses putting numbers together over a wide range of area and they're doing their own pricing, it's very hard to get it down to the tens. But right now we're comfortable in this range, which is just above 52%.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you for the clarification on that. The last question I had before deferring to others, you mentioned that the cutting tool initiative, any sense of -- I might be too early right now to really gauge early returns on that, but how ultimately are you g
componenttext: Thank you for the clarification on that. The last question I had before deferring to others, you mentioned that the cutting tool initiative, any sense of -- I might be too early right now to really gauge early returns on that, but how ultimately are you going to define success on that initiative with some mileposts? And how are we going to ascertain how that initiative is coming along from a qualification standpoint?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's too early to know that. Really how we're going to measure it is by sales growth. We expect that group of products starting out in the third quarter at some level, but probably not reporting till fourth or first to outgrow the company by a pretty
componenttext: Yes. It's too early to know that. Really how we're going to measure it is by sales growth. We expect that group of products starting out in the third quarter at some level, but probably not reporting till fourth or first to outgrow the company by a pretty wide margin. At the same time, we expect out of government the same thing we expect out of vending. If we focus on initiative, invest heavily and don't outgrow the company, then it's probably have been a bad investment for us.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: So you anticipate disclosing the sales then perhaps by year end for the investment community?
componenttext: So you anticipate disclosing the sales then perhaps by year end for the investment community?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, if you look at our 10-K, the 10-K does have product growth contribution and so it'll come out automatically in that. And I'm not sure what Dan will do beyond that. But I guess we're always reluctant to put more information because we then have to co
componenttext: Well, if you look at our 10-K, the 10-K does have product growth contribution and so it'll come out automatically in that. And I'm not sure what Dan will do beyond that. But I guess we're always reluctant to put more information because we then have to continue to support it. But we'll do it in the 10-K for sure and then we'll decide going forward beyond that.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Holden Lewis of BB&T.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Holden Lewis of BB&T.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: On this vending machine, I guess you sort of talked about what it's doing from a volume standpoint. If you have any greater insight as to why maybe those revenues are growing as much, that'd be great. You only alluded to it. But seriously, guys, as those
componenttext: On this vending machine, I guess you sort of talked about what it's doing from a volume standpoint. If you have any greater insight as to why maybe those revenues are growing as much, that'd be great. You only alluded to it. But seriously, guys, as those play out and grow in the mix, how do you expect the vending model to affect rate of employee adds and sort of what's the margin profile? Are there any differences that accrue to those areas as well from vending picking up?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: I don't think it will affect our rate of employees added. I mean if it pushed our growth up disproportionate, we'd have to add more. But vending in itself doesn't change that. It is a little more efficient, but it will take greater scale to bring that eff
componenttext: I don't think it will affect our rate of employees added. I mean if it pushed our growth up disproportionate, we'd have to add more. But vending in itself doesn't change that. It is a little more efficient, but it will take greater scale to bring that efficiency out. Other margin things, what we've done is we've taken the expense, the depreciation, the capital expense of vending, put that against our operating expenses because we look at it as nothing other than an offsite storage. And we want our leadership, our managers and DMs to think of it that way, so if they have a big vending base, they need a smaller store. We don't want incremental expenses out of this, and we believe we have that pretty well understood and positioned within our P&L and our paid programs. It's really a growth driver, and it's a solution for our customers to save money and run their businesses better. And if it really plays out to be better for our customers, it should give us long-term growth. And that's really what we're focused on. I'm probably the most bullish person on this and maybe in industrial distribution. It's a solution that works. And we continue to hear that from our customers. And the report I mentioned yesterday on the cutting tool initiative was 45% reduction in consumption. That's pretty strong argument that this solution is going to work. That is just one and we have a stack of those case studies that look just very much the same.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: One thing I'd add to that, Holden, is the question of why are you seeing the impact. I think in May, we talked about this and then in previous calls, we touched on that. But picture yourself from the standpoint of our customer. And you have a Fastenal ven
componenttext: One thing I'd add to that, Holden, is the question of why are you seeing the impact. I think in May, we talked about this and then in previous calls, we touched on that. But picture yourself from the standpoint of our customer. And you have a Fastenal vending machine or a machine physically in your plant. From the standpoint of the people that are using the product, we're a convenient way to get your usage 24/7. We are -- the Fastenal billboard physically in the plant lends itself to our name just becoming more familiar to everybody, and people think of us as the supplier of choice in that facility. And to the person who's heading up the effort on purchasing or managing the facility, if our solutions come in there and reduce your consumption by 20%, 30%, 40%, the question I'd have at the person who's doing the buying. Jeez, can I get more machines here and run more products through these kinds of solutions? And so it really puts you in a position to be the supplier of choice for that plant.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: It could also -- it gives our people a reason that they have to be in that plant on a regular basis, which leads a higher level of familiarity, a little bit of home court advantage.
componenttext: It could also -- it gives our people a reason that they have to be in that plant on a regular basis, which leads a higher level of familiarity, a little bit of home court advantage.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then just to follow up, the margins have obviously been solid. The one thing that sort of narrowed this incremental margin, which Q2 last year was 43.5%. That's going to back off each quarter from a point in Q2, which is still good but lo
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then just to follow up, the margins have obviously been solid. The one thing that sort of narrowed this incremental margin, which Q2 last year was 43.5%. That's going to back off each quarter from a point in Q2, which is still good but lower at 29.3%. As we cycle [indiscernible], what do you think that incremental margin sort of goes down to and settles in? As we look towards 2012, 2013, what kind of a mature cycle incremental margin that you guys would be targeting?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, like I said on previous calls, I really think a number around 30% is a number that's achievable. Does that become more challenging over time? Sure, it does. As your comparison number keeps rising and your comps become more difficult, it becomes more
componenttext: Well, like I said on previous calls, I really think a number around 30% is a number that's achievable. Does that become more challenging over time? Sure, it does. As your comparison number keeps rising and your comps become more difficult, it becomes more challenging. But in an environment where we're growing north of 20%, in an environment where our gross margins are stable to moderately improving and there's things that can moderately improve over time -- what we touched on earlier was the private label. In that environment, where you're getting good growth, good gross margin and you're effectively managing your operating expenses, which I believe we are doing, that puts you in a position where I'm not saying 30% number is easy. As you see, this quarter, I mean, I would just point we didn't hit 30% but 29.3% or 29.4% whatever the number was, very attractive number nonetheless. I think that's a number we can continue to strive for. Obviously, that's a challenging goal for us, but it's a goal that can be achieved. We just need to manage our -- get good sales growth. Maintain our gross margin, not only improve it and manage our operating expenses well.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: We've also been investing heavily -- intentionally investing heavily on some of these sales initiatives and do it might affect us a little bit there. But I think the decisions are very -- we really feel comfortable with those decisions and they're paying
componenttext: We've also been investing heavily -- intentionally investing heavily on some of these sales initiatives and do it might affect us a little bit there. But I think the decisions are very -- we really feel comfortable with those decisions and they're paying off in our sales growth.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Tom Hayes from Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Tom Hayes from Piper Jaffray.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'm Just wondering if you can maybe talk a little bit about the plans for store openings in the back half of the year. It was your geography that you're focusing on and then kind of thoughts on planning over 3Q and 4Q?
componenttext: I'm Just wondering if you can maybe talk a little bit about the plans for store openings in the back half of the year. It was your geography that you're focusing on and then kind of thoughts on planning over 3Q and 4Q?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our stated number for the year, the 150 to 200, we've opened 75 in the first 6 months of the year. We talked about on our first quarter call, we've touched on it a little bit in our May conference that we'd anticipate that given the energy that's going in
componenttext: Our stated number for the year, the 150 to 200, we've opened 75 in the first 6 months of the year. We talked about on our first quarter call, we've touched on it a little bit in our May conference that we'd anticipate that given the energy that's going into vending and all the other initiatives, that anything would be in the low end of that range. But on the first -- I could say, if you annualize our first 6 months, we're right at the low end of the range. We'll continue opening stores in the third and fourth quarter. And I think that range is still good, but we're putting a lot of energy into our vending, which is, I think, great for our business and great for our customers.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then kind of a follow-up question. You touched on it briefly, but I was hoping maybe you could talk about the contribution you're seeing from the specialized sales initiatives, including the National Accounts and the dedicated sales team. I think on t
componenttext: And then kind of a follow-up question. You touched on it briefly, but I was hoping maybe you could talk about the contribution you're seeing from the specialized sales initiatives, including the National Accounts and the dedicated sales team. I think on the store breakdown, it represents about 3% of your sales. I'm not sure if that's the exact representation of that. But what are your expectations for the groups over the next couple of years?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think when you refer to that, you're talking about our strategic count stores when you say that 3%. There's a little disconnect there and maybe we could improve the [indiscernible] on how we disclose that. When we talk about our national accounts, we ta
componenttext: I think when you refer to that, you're talking about our strategic count stores when you say that 3%. There's a little disconnect there and maybe we could improve the [indiscernible] on how we disclose that. When we talk about our national accounts, we talk about our sales initiatives. These are initiatives to raise the tide in all of our stores. There are things that help our stores grow faster, whether that store is the $150,000 a month store down the street here or -- excuse me, over in the middle of Wisconsin or if it's the $40,000 a month store out on the West Coast. It's things that can help raise the tide and give that store manager and district manager more things in their arsenal for growing their business. When we talk about our strategic account stores, that's just a subset of stores, and we originally carve those out, is we like to show the economics of the store model especially when we started the 'pathway to profit' because it really allows us a better means to explain it. But the initiatives are not solely in that strategic count store. They're across all stores. All we're trying to do in that table is show you a peer [ph] look at here is your $60,000 to $100,000 store. Here's your $100,000 to $150,000 store and what their economics look like. And we carved out both our strategic count stores and our overseas stores. But short of that, a sale is a sale and it goes through any business unit.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ryan Merkel of William Blair.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ryan Merkel of William Blair.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: My first question is on the vending. So what are some of the more recent contract signings, the common installed units? Is the real current cumulative installed base closer to 5,000 machines? Is that the right way to look at it? 2,900 machines?
componenttext: My first question is on the vending. So what are some of the more recent contract signings, the common installed units? Is the real current cumulative installed base closer to 5,000 machines? Is that the right way to look at it? 2,900 machines?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: The cumulative installed machines at the end of the quarter was just over 4,000 machines. And in the first figure, what we're really try to do is communicate what's the pace. How many machines are we signing that quarter, and there's always going to be a
componenttext: The cumulative installed machines at the end of the quarter was just over 4,000 machines. And in the first figure, what we're really try to do is communicate what's the pace. How many machines are we signing that quarter, and there's always going to be a lag. The machine that we signed up the last week of June, or June in general, those machines -- what happens after a machine is signed, you sit down with a customer and you go through and you decide what SKUs are going to go into this machine. And we're working every day to shorten that window up and provide our customers with better information. Basically, provide them here's what we think would work for your business. But there's always going to be that lag between the deciding process and what products go in and then they're then actually placing the machines in the plant. But at the end of the quarter, we had just over 4,000 machines. If you look at it, we -- the jump up from Q3 to Q4 and then from Q4 to Q1 and then Q1 to Q2, really is a lag from the signings in the table right above it.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: We have -- basically, most of the machines we signed in the second quarter have not been installed. We have about a 90-day backlog, which is great from a go forward on sales. But our frustration, mine and Dan's and the other leaders', is let's shorten tha
componenttext: We have -- basically, most of the machines we signed in the second quarter have not been installed. We have about a 90-day backlog, which is great from a go forward on sales. But our frustration, mine and Dan's and the other leaders', is let's shorten that up to 50 or 60. Most of that is being held up at the customer side with them struggling to make the decision on what do I put in the machine. And we're working hard to give them, to give the customers better tools, give our people better tools. And our goal is to get that down. We'll probably not get it much below 60 days. It just takes a certain amount of time to do the end, so part of it is they have to bring in clean Internet lines outside of their system. And that's always -- in many cases, it takes 8 weeks just to get the Internet lines. Because the customer doesn't want this running through their IT system. They want a fresh line outside of the plant. There are a lot of details that I'm not familiar with, that I don't know exactly how they work. So we have a big backlog installed, and we have great momentum on signings.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: That's what I figured. I just thought I'd get some clarification. And then second question, can you just talk about June, how did the month play out, and then maybe speak to geographic or customer strength?
componenttext: That's what I figured. I just thought I'd get some clarification. And then second question, can you just talk about June, how did the month play out, and then maybe speak to geographic or customer strength?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. Actually, June started off a little soft and I was starting to believe the ISM for a few days there. Actually, I believed in it, but it started off soft. It came in at a very strong finish in June, the strongest finish we've ever had, which has reall
componenttext: Yes. Actually, June started off a little soft and I was starting to believe the ISM for a few days there. Actually, I believed in it, but it started off soft. It came in at a very strong finish in June, the strongest finish we've ever had, which has really turned out to be a good month. Geographically, it was pretty even. We don't have any real soft spots. If anything, the eastern half of the United States is a little softer than the west. I think a little bit of that is driven by a little uncertainty in the auto industry or there was some uncertainty there in the late May and some of that. Overall, the entire business did well. International did exceptionally well. It grew at about almost 50%. Regionally, there was no one that was doing great. Some of the areas like the Southwest, the oil belt down there has cooled off a little bit. They're still ahead of the company, but in the first quarter they were well ahead of the company. So that softened up a little bit. Midwest remained strong. And I think a lot of that is being driven by optimism in the ag industry and a lot of the agricultural business is doing really well with a $7 corn. If you look at numbers closely, there's really no way that's soft.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think what helps balance that and one of the things that helped us put up the [indiscernible] sales growth we saw in the second quarter is we just -- there's so many things that are working under the surface. And by working, I mean so many pieces in mot
componenttext: I think what helps balance that and one of the things that helped us put up the [indiscernible] sales growth we saw in the second quarter is we just -- there's so many things that are working under the surface. And by working, I mean so many pieces in motion under the surface. You know, store openings, adding people, adding sales energy, the vending, the government, the cutting tools, the manufacturing. You look at all these pieces -- the international. You have all these pieces. So as Will mentioned, you have an area that's red hot that's just hot. But then, 5 other areas stepped up to fill the void a little bit and you continue to put up really attractive numbers. So nothing really stands out as a particular geographic area that's unusually strong or unusually weak.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Robert Barry of UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Robert Barry of UBS.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: I wanted to just clarify earlier comment about pricing and inflation. It sounds like, in the quarter, you didn't see much benefit from pricing nor did you see much impact from product inflation. Is that accurate?
componenttext: I wanted to just clarify earlier comment about pricing and inflation. It sounds like, in the quarter, you didn't see much benefit from pricing nor did you see much impact from product inflation. Is that accurate?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: That is correct.
componenttext: That is correct.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. In the fasteners, we saw 6 to 8 months ago a little bit of price increase. But it's like a rolling hill. It's been moving up and down for the last 12 months. If you look at the CRM [ph] steel index, it moves up and then slides down. I spent the last
componenttext: Yes. In the fasteners, we saw 6 to 8 months ago a little bit of price increase. But it's like a rolling hill. It's been moving up and down for the last 12 months. If you look at the CRM [ph] steel index, it moves up and then slides down. I spent the last week of April in Asia visiting factories, talking to a lot of people I've known for years about pricing because I was curious. The Taiwanese and Chinese, they're going -- it's not going to go up a lot. A lot of it is because the demand is ho hum. The demand is good, but not great. And they just don't feel they can push price increase. So we look at it as a very stable -- chances of it going up are probably greater than going down, but we don't see a lot of movement in either direction.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Even on the non-fastener side?
componenttext: Even on the non-fastener side?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Even on the non-fastener side because oil has been stable. It's been stable at $100 a barrel, but it's been in a similar range. It hasn't been going up and down a lot outside of the range and so that's a big component in the plastics and some of the other
componenttext: Even on the non-fastener side because oil has been stable. It's been stable at $100 a barrel, but it's been in a similar range. It hasn't been going up and down a lot outside of the range and so that's a big component in the plastics and some of the other products we sell. I think part of it, too, is the industrial economy is good, but still not an environment where you can push price increases a lot from the supplier base. Our suppliers are pushing and we're fighting back and in most cases we more than we lose.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then I also wanted to get in a vending question. You think you're cutting the usage so much for the customers, but still seeing that significant growth at the customers with vending. It implies some pretty significant share gain. I'm just wondering wh
componenttext: And then I also wanted to get in a vending question. You think you're cutting the usage so much for the customers, but still seeing that significant growth at the customers with vending. It implies some pretty significant share gain. I'm just wondering where that's coming from? Is that share gain coming from other large suppliers -- I'm sorry, distributors? Or are you resting it more from the small mom and pops?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's really impossible for us to tell. And you have to look at it in the scheme of things. We're doing roughly $30 million -- less than $30 million coming from a broad range. It's hard to tell. A little bit from here, a little bit from there. So every cus
componenttext: It's really impossible for us to tell. And you have to look at it in the scheme of things. We're doing roughly $30 million -- less than $30 million coming from a broad range. It's hard to tell. A little bit from here, a little bit from there. So every customer is buying from someone else. It's no different than opening a store and taking market. We take a little from everyone if we can. And if we win 2 and lose 1, we're going to end up stronger tomorrow.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. Then, just finally if I could sneak one last one in on the government contracts. You're clearly making a bigger push there. As that becomes a more significant part of the business, I was just wondering how you think about pricing on the government c
componenttext: Okay. Then, just finally if I could sneak one last one in on the government contracts. You're clearly making a bigger push there. As that becomes a more significant part of the business, I was just wondering how you think about pricing on the government contracts could impact pricing across the rest of the business. My sense is that sometimes governments require that they get "the best price." Does that sort have implications for the way you think about pricing across the rest of the business as the government piece gets bigger?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, the contracts that we are picking picked up our -- it's the Westerns States Cooperative Alliance, which is a WSCA state cooperative alliance contract. We get that and it doesn't say best pricing everywhere. It's very competitive. Federal governments
componenttext: Well, the contracts that we are picking picked up our -- it's the Westerns States Cooperative Alliance, which is a WSCA state cooperative alliance contract. We get that and it doesn't say best pricing everywhere. It's very competitive. Federal governments are usually the ones that dictate that they always get the lowest price. And at this time, we don't have a federal government contract that says that. And we have to be very cautious with that because we have a lot of decentralization within our markets. So we're very aware of the rules. We're not going to pick up any business that would affect our overall pricing strategy because that would be detrimental to the rest of the team.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: But you had a disadvantage as you go after that federal business?
componenttext: But you had a disadvantage as you go after that federal business?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, we just have to understand what the contracts are. You know what, if it does put us at a disadvantage, we'll walk away from it. Because again we're not going to take on one piece of business even if it was a large piece that affects the other $2 billi
componenttext: No, we just have to understand what the contracts are. You know what, if it does put us at a disadvantage, we'll walk away from it. Because again we're not going to take on one piece of business even if it was a large piece that affects the other $2 billion or $3 billion that we do. So we're not set up for all business.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: There's a lot of things that we do that puts us in a better position and a worse position for things in life. We like to make money on all of our business. Some customers -- some situations you can't make money and you walk away from it.
componenttext: There's a lot of things that we do that puts us in a better position and a worse position for things in life. We like to make money on all of our business. Some customers -- some situations you can't make money and you walk away from it.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. And we have to look at the effect on the overall business. You did something so low, then you have to reduce the price of your business. That's bad business. So we're looking at all the opportunities and not all of them have those qualities. Many of
componenttext: Yes. And we have to look at the effect on the overall business. You did something so low, then you have to reduce the price of your business. That's bad business. So we're looking at all the opportunities and not all of them have those qualities. Many of them don't.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Hamzah Mazari of Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Hamzah Mazari of Credit Suisse.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just a question on your store closings. It seems like those have picked up slightly. Could you maybe comment on what you're thinking going forward on shutting down stores and any potential cannibalization that you're seeing in terms of your store numbers?
componenttext: Just a question on your store closings. It seems like those have picked up slightly. Could you maybe comment on what you're thinking going forward on shutting down stores and any potential cannibalization that you're seeing in terms of your store numbers?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: Actually, our store closings in the first 6 months of this year were identical to our store closings in the first 6 months of last year. I think being willing to look objectively at everything you do and assessing everything you do every day is a healthy
componenttext: Actually, our store closings in the first 6 months of this year were identical to our store closings in the first 6 months of last year. I think being willing to look objectively at everything you do and assessing everything you do every day is a healthy thing for our business. And if I look at where we have had closings, it's typically a situation where our districts or regional leadership has looked at our their opportunities in a market and said, I have a great market. It might be a market that I had 3 stores. I went to 4. I have a lease coming due in one of the stores, and I think I could serve the market better with 3 than 4. And in an environment where I have all the things in my arsenal, including vending, that might be a better solution. When I look at cumulatively how many we've closed over a 40-year period, the number is inconsequential. I think it's a healthy way to look at your business everyday of saying, what do I do to make my business better in this market, in this district, in this region. And so I don't think it means a lot for our business on a go-forward basis. It just means we'll have a good, healthy assessment of everything we do.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. And then, just a follow-up question. Did you guys see any benefit from weather in Q2? What I mean by that is any negative sales growth due to weather in Q1? Did you see any of that get pushed out into the second quarter?
componenttext: That's very helpful. And then, just a follow-up question. Did you guys see any benefit from weather in Q2? What I mean by that is any negative sales growth due to weather in Q1? Did you see any of that get pushed out into the second quarter?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 12, 2011
componenttextpreview: No. Normally, when there are weather delays or when you lose weather, or you lose business to weather, you very seldom ever make it up because it just gets pushed further out. If a construction job gets shut down for a week, the whole thing slides back a
componenttext: No. Normally, when there are weather delays or when you lose weather, or you lose business to weather, you very seldom ever make it up because it just gets pushed further out. If a construction job gets shut down for a week, the whole thing slides back a week. So really we didn't see any of that. We did have generally good weather in the second quarter, other than all the tornadoes and the flooding. And that usually balance us out. But initially, what happens after a big flood or a tornado is most of the plant shut down because the people are working with their -- sorry, Dan's [indiscernible], people are working to take care of their parents' houses and other things. So overall, too small to measure if there was an effect.
